conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph and find the corresponding velocity and position functions.
The graph shows acceleration (a) as a function of time (t). The acceleration changes linearly over time, forming a triangular waveform.

premise: The graph shows acceleration (a) as a function of time (t).
conclusion: The graph can be divided into three intervals: 0 to t0/2, t0/2 to t0, t0 to 2t0.
Velocity (v) is the integral of acceleration (a) with respect to time. Start from rest, so initial velocity v(0) = 0.

premise: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0 in interval 1.
Acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0 in interval 2.
Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -a0 in interval 3.

conclusion: Position (x) is the integral of velocity (v) with respect to time. Start from rest, so initial position x(0) = 0.
